Lieutenant Governor shows up uninvited to a Marine's funeral.
 
 Some people just have no taste.
I read about this one and thought it was absolutely disgusting. It shows how disconnected some (if not all) politicians have become from the average normal person and the real world.

Are funerals by invitation only these days?
 
 I am aware that when famous people die and there's likely to be a crush at the services, access to these funerals are restricted. Also, I believe that in a number of other states, state officials try to show up for the funerals of those who have been killed in combat.
 
 What are the exact circumstances of this little brouhaha? Did Knoll walk in with a campaign sign and hand out pamphlets as she went to her seat? Has she been to other funerals for combat victims? Did she make campaign speeches at these funerals?

Funerals of normal people (i.e. not celebrities) are usually done by invitation (at least in my country).
 Crashing a funeral, handing out a business card and campaigning is really in bad taste.
It was extremely bad taste, poor judgement, and all around deplorable behavior that hopefully will be rewarded with being voted out

Obviously we live in different coutries. Most funerals in the U.S. are open to anyone who happens by, unless special arrangements have been made.
 
 As a matter of fact, I crashed a funeral of a noted architect and designer because his funeral was being held in a church he had had a hand in designing. Loved the design of the church, a few looked askance at me as I dug into the posh grub afterwards but I, unblushingly, said something about liking his work as an architect and dug in.
 
 Also, although a rabid non-Catholic I have attended the funerals of a nun I admired, a bishop I did not admire so much--I skipped the after funeral social gathering.
 
 If I should choose to attend the funeral of a local person who died in combat in Iraq, I am very sure that I would be welcome to do so, unless the church were already crowded. And, again, a great many state officials IN THE UNITED STATES have felt that it was their duty to be present at funeral services for state residents who had been killed in combat. Those who go in an official capacity to these services go to honor the memory of the deceased.
 
 In instances where the funeral is private, I believe that that is usually announced in the obituary and I would certainly think that persons would be stationed at the doors to the services to turn away those who were not invited. Was that the case in this particular funeral?

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Is traditional campaigning dead?
